mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Member States of the European Union

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Centre d'études et de recherches internationales

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Member States of the European Union combines an analysis of individual EU member states with the effects of Europeanization on domestic institutions and policies. Examining both sides of this crucial relationship, it is the best guide to EU member state relations available. The second edition has been thoroughly updated to take in the latest round of EU enlargement and includes chapters on eight member states from different geographical regions and dates of accession. These are followed by seven thematic chapters on the Europeanization of structures, actors, and processes within the EU 27.
mods:mods.mods:tableOfContents: 1: Simon Bulmer & Christian Lequesne: The European Union and its Member States: An Overview Part 1 Analysis 2: Paolo R. Graziano and Maarten P. Vink: Europeanization: Concept, Theory and Methods Part 2 The Member States 3: Olivier Rozenberg: Genuine Europeanization or Monnet for Nothing? 4: Timm Beichelt: Germany: In Search of a New Balance 5: David Allen: The United Kingdom: Towards Isolation and a Parting of the Ways? 6: Francesc Morata: Spain: Modernization through Europeanization 7: Anna Michalski: Sweden: From Scepticism to Pragmatic Support 8: Nathaniel Copsey: Poland: An Awkward Partner Redeemed 9: Piret Ehin: Estonia: Excelling at Self-Exertion 10: Dimitris Papadimitriou and David Phinnemore: Romania: Uneven Europeanization 11: Simon Bulmer and Christian Lequesne: Contrasting States of Europeanization Part 3 Europeanization 12: Hussein Kassim: Europeanization and Member State Institutions 13: Robert Ladrech: Europeanization and Political Parties 14: Sabine Saurugger: The Europeanization of Interest Groups and Social Movements 15: Simon Bulmer and Claudio M. Radaelli: The Europeanization of Member State Policy 16: Peter Bursens: Europeanization and Sub-national Authorities 17: Vivien A. Schmidt: The Europeanization of National Economies Simon Bulmer and Christian Lequesne: Conclusion
